**Mercedes-AMG GmbH** , commonly known as **AMG** , is the high performance
division of [Mercedes-Benz](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz "Mercedes-Benz"). AMG
independently hires engineers, manufactures and customizes Mercedes-Benz AMG
vehicles. Mercedes-AMG is headquartered in [Affalterbach](/wiki/Affalterbach
"Affalterbach"), [Baden-Württemberg](/wiki/Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg "Baden-
Württemberg"), Germany. AMG was originally an independent engineering firm
specializing in performance improvements for Mercedes-Benz vehicles; Daimler-
Benz AG took a controlling interest in 1999, then became sole owner of AMG in
2005. Mercedes-AMG GmbH is now a wholly owned subsidiary of [Daimler
AG](/wiki/Daimler_AG "Daimler AG").

AMG models typically have more aggressive looks, a higher level of
performance, better handling, better stability and more extensive use of
carbon fibre than their regular Mercedes-Benz counterparts.[2] AMG models are
typically the most expensive and highest-performing variant of each Mercedes-
Benz class.[2]

AMG variants are usually badged with two numerals, as opposed to regular
Mercedes-Benz vehicles, which have three (e.g., _C 63_ as opposed to _C
350_).[3] Traditionally, the two numerical digits signified the engine's
displacement size, however, recent models have deviated from such correlation.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-AMG&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Mercedes_AMG_C63_W204_amk.jpg/220px-
Mercedes_AMG_C63_W204_amk.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mercedes_AMG_C63_W204_amk.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mercedes_AMG_C63_W204_amk.jpg "Enlarge")

AMG logo on a Mercedes C63 AMG (W204)

AMG was founded as a racing engine forge in 1967 under the name _AMG
Motorenbau und Entwicklungsgesellschaft mbH_ (_AMG Engine Production and
Development, Ltd._), by former Mercedes-Benz engineers [Hans Werner
Aufrecht](/wiki/Hans_Werner_Aufrecht "Hans Werner Aufrecht") and [Erhard
Melcher](/wiki/Erhard_Melcher "Erhard Melcher") in [Burgstall an der
Murr](/wiki/Burgstetten "Burgstetten"), near [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart
"Stuttgart"). The letters "AMG" stand for Aufrecht, Melcher and
[Großaspach](/wiki/Gro%C3%9Faspach "Großaspach") (Aufrecht's birth town). In
1976 most of AMG moved to Affalterbach, with the racing-engine development
remaining at the old location in Burgstall. At this time Erhard Melcher ceased
to be a partner, but continued to be an employee at the Burgstall location.

In 1993, with AMG having become a high-profile purveyor of modified Mercedes-
Benz cars, Daimler-Benz AG and AMG signed a contract of cooperation, allowing
AMG to leverage Daimler-Benz's extensive dealer network and leading to
commonly developed vehicles (the first one being the Mercedes-Benz C36 AMG, in
1993). On 1 January 1999 DaimlerChrysler, as it was called between 1998 and
2007, acquired 51 percent of AMG shares, and AMG was renamed to Mercedes-AMG
GmbH.[4] Racing engine development was divested and continues to exist in
Burgstall under the name [HWA](/wiki/HWA_AG "HWA AG") (Aufrecht's initials).
On 1 January 2005 Aufrecht sold his remaining shares to DaimlerChrysler, and
since then Mercedes-AMG GmbH has been a wholly owned subsidiary of Daimler
AG.[1]

### Development of the product range[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Development of the product range")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Ats_amgpenta.jpg/220px-
Ats_amgpenta.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ats_amgpenta.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ats_amgpenta.jpg "Enlarge")

AMG Five Spoke Road Wheel 8JX16 Version 1

AMG started off by designing and testing racing engines. It expanded its
business into building _custom_ road cars based upon standard Mercedes cars.
AMG initially produced a range of unofficial upgrade and accessories packages
mainly for the [Mercedes-Benz R107 and C107](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_R107_and_C107
"Mercedes-Benz R107 and C107") (1971-1989 SL roadster),[5] [Mercedes-Benz
W116](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W116 "Mercedes-Benz W116") (1972-1980 S-class),
[Mercedes-Benz W123](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W123 "Mercedes-Benz W123") (1976-1985
E-class), [Mercedes-Benz W124](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W124 "Mercedes-Benz W124")
(1984-1997 E-class), [Mercedes-Benz W126](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W126 "Mercedes-
Benz W126") (1979-1992 S-class), [Mercedes-Benz R129](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_R129
"Mercedes-Benz R129") (1989-2001 SL roadster), and [Mercedes-Benz
W201](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W201 "Mercedes-Benz W201") (1982-1993 C-class)
models.

During the early 1980s and up until 1990, AMG offered a variety of engine
performance packages, alloy wheels and styling products as an entirely
independent company from Daimler-Benz. In 1990, AMG signed a co-operation
agreement with Daimler-Benz, and AMG options and cars were then offered in
Mercedes-Benz showrooms; in 1999 Daimler AG, then known as DaimlerChrysler AG,
bought the controlling share of AMG and made them part of the official
Mercedes-Benz line-up.[6]

Typical AMG performance enhancements, which the buyer could custom order,
included increased engine displacements (5.2 litre, 5.4 litre), performance
top ends with port and polished heads and intake, lightened valve train, and
more aggressive cams. The DOHC 32V engine had also just been developed and was
the pinnacle of AMG performance. A Getrag five-speed manual transmission could
be ordered from AMG, and Mercedes had not offered a manual transmission V8
since the early 1970s.

The performance wheels offered during the same period were 15-inch or 16-inch
[ATS](/wiki/ATS_\(wheels\) "ATS \(wheels\)") AMG Five Spoke Road Wheels,
commonly referred to as Pentas. Penta was actually a UK-based company that
supplemented the high demand for the AMG wheel at the time with a replica and
only a very slight styling difference, but they were not made or endorsed by
AMG. The genuine AMG wheels were often coupled with an AMG performance
suspension package that included uprated and lowered springs, and re-valved
shock absorbers.

Another popular cosmetic upgrade were the AMG body kits. These ranged from
subtle front spoilers, to an aggressive Wide Body kits for the W126 coupes.
Other options included [Recaro](/wiki/Recaro "Recaro") seats, smaller diameter
steering wheels, instrument clusters, chrome delete option (all brightworks
colour-coded or painted satin black), refrigerators, shift knobs, hi-fi stereo
systems, custom upholstery and enhanced interior wood packages.

The release of the AMG Hammer sedan in 1986, based on the [W124
E-Class](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W124 "Mercedes-Benz W124"), took AMG's
performance modifications for a fast midsized sedan to a new level. AMG made
the world's fastest passenger sedan at the time, nicknamed the Hammer,[7] by
squeezing Mercedes 5.6-litre V8 tuned by AMG to 360 hp into a midsized sedan.
It was very aggressive for the era, with 32-valve cylinder heads and twin
camshafts, and said to be faster than the [Lamborghini
Countach](/wiki/Lamborghini_Countach "Lamborghini Countach") from 60 to 120
mph.[8] Later models were even more powerful and introduced the 17-inch AMG
Aero 1 Hammer wheels. 1986 was also the year Mercedes introduced the 560 M117
engine. This provided yet another opportunity for customers to order the
largest AMG displacement available at the time, the 6L 100 mm bore SOHC or
DOHC engines available for both the W126 coupe and sedans.

Through the early 2000s, AMG focused principally on
[supercharged](/wiki/Supercharged "Supercharged") V8 and V6 engines, but the
company officially abandoned this technology in 2006 with the introduction of
the naturally aspirated 6.2 L [M156 V8](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M156_engine
"Mercedes-Benz M156 engine"). On 16 January 2006, Mercedes-AMG Chairman Volker
Mornhinweg told [AutoWeek](/wiki/AutoWeek "AutoWeek") that the company would
use [turbocharging](/wiki/Turbocharging "Turbocharging") for higher output
rather than supercharging. For 2011, AMG released the M157 5.5L biturbo V8,
which has supplanted the M156 in its full-sized cars such as the S-Class and
CL-Class (and is trickling down to the CLS, E-Class and ML-class). In 2012,
Mercedes-AMG Chairman Olla Kallenius said that Mercedes-AMG will not produce
diesel engines to compete with BMW's tri-turbo diesels (BMW M Performance
range).[9]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/DTM_Mercedes_AMG.jpg/220px-
DTM_Mercedes_AMG.jpg)](/wiki/File:DTM_Mercedes_AMG.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DTM_Mercedes_AMG.jpg "Enlarge")

Mercedes AMG DTM car (2003)

Although there were some AMG models in the 1980s with manual transmissions,
almost all recent models have used automatics ([5G-Tronic](/wiki/5G-Tronic
"5G-Tronic") and later [7G-Tronic](/wiki/7G-Tronic "7G-Tronic") with
Speedshift), in contrast to [BMW M](/wiki/BMW_M "BMW M"), which used manuals
and recently [semi-automatic transmissions](/wiki/Semi-automatic_transmission
"Semi-automatic transmission") (the current type being a [dual clutch
transmission](/wiki/Dual_clutch_transmission "Dual clutch transmission")).
Starting in 2009, however, AMG began adopting the [seven-speed AMG SpeedShift
MCT](/wiki/7G-Tronic#AMG_SpeedShift_MCT "7G-Tronic") automatic transmission.

Although these are considered the most well known in-house tuning divisions,
Mercedes-AMG has a considerably different philosophy than [BMW M](/wiki/BMW_M
"BMW M"). Mercedes-AMG has created high-performance versions of many of its
nameplates, including flagship sedans and SUVs, while BMW M has emphasized
tuning only vehicles with "Lateral agility" (which has long been only their 3
Series, 5 Series, and roadsters).[10] Compared to BMW M, Mercedes-AMG is "less
narrow in its sporting focus, yet still combining sledgehammer performance
with relaxed handling, cultured comfort, and practicality".[11]

While founders Hans Werner Aufrecht and Erhard Melcher had emphasized proper
racing cars, Mercedes-AMG had diverged considerably from this philosophy in
recent years, with their offerings being well known for straight-line
acceleration but poor handling dynamics. However, current Mercedes-AMG
chairman [Volker
Mornhinweg](/w/index.php?title=Volker_Mornhinweg&action=edit&redlink=1 "Volker
Mornhinweg \(page does not exist\)") has urged the division to return to its
roots of building sports cars.[12]

### Motor racing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-AMG&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Motor racing")]

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, AMG entered the big [Mercedes-Benz 300SEL
6.3](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_300SEL_6.3 "Mercedes-Benz 300SEL 6.3") V8 saloon,
affectionately named the "Red Sow", in the 1971 [Spa 24
Hours](/wiki/Spa_24_Hours "Spa 24 Hours"), and the [European Touring Car
Championship](/wiki/European_Touring_Car_Championship "European Touring Car
Championship"). AMG and Mercedes worked together on [Mercedes-Benz
W201](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W201 "Mercedes-Benz W201") cars for the 1988
[Deutsche Tourenwagen Meisterschaft](/wiki/Deutsche_Tourenwagen_Meisterschaft
"Deutsche Tourenwagen Meisterschaft") (DTM, German Touring Car Championship).
AMG was made the official partner.

When DaimlerChrysler acquired a majority share of AMG in 1999, the motor
racing department was divested into [HWA AG](/wiki/HWA_AG "HWA AG"). Their
first car was the ill-fated [Mercedes-Benz CLR](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CLR
"Mercedes-Benz CLR"). Since 2000, HWA builds and runs the cars for [Deutsche
Tourenwagen Masters](/wiki/Deutsche_Tourenwagen_Masters "Deutsche Tourenwagen
Masters") (DTM), as well as the M271 engine tuned for use in [Formula
3](/wiki/Formula_3 "Formula 3").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/AMG_Mercedes_V12.jpg/220px-
AMG_Mercedes_V12.jpg)](/wiki/File:AMG_Mercedes_V12.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:AMG_Mercedes_V12.jpg "Enlarge")

AMG engine display at the Pagani factory

Six successive lightly modified Mercedes-Benz AMG models (including, most
recently, an SL 63 AMG) have acted as the [safety cars](/wiki/Safety_car
"Safety car") for the
[FIA](/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_l%27Automobile "Fédération
Internationale de l'Automobile") [Formula One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula
One") World Championship.

Since 2010, the [Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG GT3s](/wiki/Mercedes-
Benz_SLS_AMG#SLS_AMG_GT3 "Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG") has been competing in GT
competitions around the world, such as the [FIA GT3 European
Championship](/wiki/FIA_GT3_European_Championship "FIA GT3 European
Championship"), [Blancpain Endurance Series](/wiki/Blancpain_Endurance_Series
"Blancpain Endurance Series"), [Blancpain Sprint
Series](/wiki/Blancpain_Sprint_Series "Blancpain Sprint Series"),
[VLN](/wiki/VLN "VLN"), [24 Hours of
Nurburgring](/wiki/24_Hours_of_Nurburgring "24 Hours of Nurburgring"),
[British GT Championship](/wiki/British_GT_Championship "British GT
Championship"), [Super GT](/wiki/Super_GT "Super GT"), [Australian GT
Championship](/wiki/Australian_GT_Championship "Australian GT Championship"),
[Bathurst 12 Hour](/wiki/Bathurst_12_Hour "Bathurst 12 Hour"), [Dubai 24
Hour](/wiki/Dubai_24_Hour "Dubai 24 Hour"), [Macau GT
Cup](/wiki/Macau_Grand_Prix "Macau Grand Prix") and [Pirelli World
Challenge](/wiki/Pirelli_World_Challenge "Pirelli World Challenge").

In late 2011, after the end of the [Formula One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula
One") season, [Mercedes GP Petronas](/wiki/Mercedes_GP_Petronas "Mercedes GP
Petronas") announced that it would be using the AMG branding for its F1
efforts, changing its name to [Mercedes AMG
Petronas](/wiki/Mercedes_GP_Petronas "Mercedes GP Petronas") for the 2012
season onwards.[13]

Three AMG E Class V8 Supercars began competing Australian [V8
Supercars](/wiki/V8_Supercars "V8 Supercars") Championship from 2013, with the
newly formed partnership of Erebus Motorsport and Stone Brothers Racing Teams
operating under a Customer Sports Program of AMG.[14]

### Relationship with Pagani[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Relationship with Pagani")]

AMG also provides engines for the [Zonda](/wiki/Pagani_Zonda "Pagani Zonda")
and [Huayra](/wiki/Pagani_Huayra "Pagani Huayra") cars. The engines used are
variants of the [M120](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M120_engine "Mercedes-Benz M120
engine") 7,291 cc displacement V12 engine originally used in the [1995 SL73
AMG](/wiki/SL-Class#AMG "SL-Class"). The M120 is the largest displacement
naturally aspirated engine provided by AMG and is now exclusively used by
Pagani.

### Relationship with Aston Martin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Relationship with Aston Martin")]

On July 25, 2013, [Aston Martin Lagonda Ltd](/wiki/Aston_Martin "Aston
Martin") and Daimler AG announced moves towards a technical partnership with
Mercedes-AMG GmbH. The deal will see Aston Martin access significant Mercedes-
AMG GmbH and Mercedes-Benz Cars' resources, allowing the development of
bespoke V8 powertrains and the use of certain components of
electric/electronic architecture. Daimler AG now owns a stake of 5% of non-
voting shares in Aston Martin, joining existing shareholders [Investment
DAR](/w/index.php?title=Investment_DAR&action=edit&redlink=1 "Investment DAR
\(page does not exist\)"), [Adeem Investment](/wiki/Adeem_Investment "Adeem
Investment") and
[Investindustrial](/w/index.php?title=Investindustrial&action=edit&redlink=1
"Investindustrial \(page does not exist\)"). The technical partnership will
support Aston Martin’s launch of a new generation of models and newly
developed bespoke V8 powertrains.[15][16][17]

## Current AMG models[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Current AMG models")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/AMG_carbon_fiber_engine.JPG/220px-
AMG_carbon_fiber_engine.JPG)](/wiki/File:AMG_carbon_fiber_engine.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:AMG_carbon_fiber_engine.JPG "Enlarge")

AMG carbon fibre engine cover

All AMG [engines](/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine "Internal combustion
engine") \- with the exception of the "43" M276 3.0 L V6 Bi-Turbo engine - are
hand built using a "one man, one engine" philosophy at the current AMG plant
in Affalterbach, Germany. To signify this, each AMG engine builder stamps the
engines they produce with an engraved plaque depicting their signature.
According to Mercedes-Benz, there are only about 50 AMG engine builders.[18]

As part of the official Mercedes product line, the AMG models are sold side-
by-side with regular production models, unlike those offered by other Mercedes
tuning firms such as [Brabus](/wiki/Brabus "Brabus").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Amg_carbon_ceramic_brake_geneva_auto_show_2011.JPG/220px-
Amg_carbon_ceramic_brake_geneva_auto_show_2011.JPG)](/wiki/File:Amg_carbon_ceramic_brake_geneva_auto_show_2011.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Amg_carbon_ceramic_brake_geneva_auto_show_2011.JPG "Enlarge")

E63 AMG carbon ceramic brake Geneva auto show 2011

### "45" M133 2.0 L Inline-4 Turbo[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: "45" M133 2.0 L Inline-4 Turbo")]

  * [Mercedes-AMG A 45](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_A-Class "Mercedes-Benz A-Class")
  * [Mercedes-AMG CLA 45](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CLA-Class "Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class")
  * [Mercedes-AMG GLA 45](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_GLA-Class "Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class")

The 2.0 L Turbo I4 was created for use in the smaller, 45 AMG models, such as
the A-Class, CLA-Class, and GLA-Class, which all share the same platform. The
M133 produces 360 PS and 332 ft-lb,[19] making it the most powerful turbo
4-cylinder in production, and with a 190.5-horsepower per liter, one of the
most power dense engines in production.[20] Models with the M133 Turbo 4 are
paired with a 7-speed AMG SPEEDSHIFT Dual-Clutch Transmission. The CLA45 AMG
can accelerate from 0-60 in 4.2 seconds, according to Motor Trend's first test
of the vehicle.[21]

### "63" M157 5.5 L V8 Bi-Turbo[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: "63" M157 5.5 L V8 Bi-Turbo")]

  * [M157](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M157_engine "Mercedes-Benz M157 engine") L 5.5 V8 models ([Twin-turbo](/wiki/Twin-turbo "Twin-turbo")) 
    * [Mercedes-AMG CLS 63](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CLS-Class#CLS_63_AMG_.282011.E2.80.93.29 "Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class")
    * [Mercedes-AMG E 63](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_E-Class_\(W212\) "Mercedes-Benz E-Class \(W212\)")
    * [Mercedes-AMG G 63](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_G-Class "Mercedes-Benz G-Class")
    * [Mercedes-AMG GLE 63](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M-Class "Mercedes-Benz M-Class")
    * [Mercedes-AMG GLS 63](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_GL-Class "Mercedes-Benz GL-Class")
    * [Mercedes-AMG S 63](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_S-Class_\(W222\) "Mercedes-Benz S-Class \(W222\)")
    * [Mercedes-AMG SL 63](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_SL-Class_\(R231\) "Mercedes-Benz SL-Class \(R231\)")

Rumoured in 2009 and confirmed in 2010, AMG developed the M157, a 5.5-litre V8
with direct fuel injection and [twin turbochargers](/wiki/Twin-turbo "Twin-
turbo"). Power is rated at up to 577 bhp (430 kW; 585 PS) at 5,250-5,750rpm
with a peak torque of 664 lb·ft (900 N·m) made between 2,000rpm and 4,500rpm
(the amount of power and torque depends on model, but these are the maximum
ratings).[22][23] Both engines are mated to Mercedes-Benz's
[7-speed](/wiki/7G-Tronic#AMG_SpeedShift_MCT "7G-Tronic") [MCT
transmission](/wiki/Dual-clutch_transmission "Dual-clutch
transmission").[24][25][26]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Mercedes_Benz_CLS_63_AMG_4Matic_2013.jpg/220px-
Mercedes_Benz_CLS_63_AMG_4Matic_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mercedes_Benz_CLS_63_AMG_4Matic_2013.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mercedes_Benz_CLS_63_AMG_4Matic_2013.jpg "Enlarge")

Mercedes-Benz CLS63 AMG

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Silver_Mercedes-
Benz_E_63_AMG_%28S212%29_fr.jpg/220px-Silver_Mercedes-
Benz_E_63_AMG_%28S212%29_fr.jpg)](/wiki/File:Silver_Mercedes-
Benz_E_63_AMG_\(S212\)_fr.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Silver_Mercedes-Benz_E_63_AMG_\(S212\)_fr.jpg "Enlarge")

E63 AMG 4MATIC T

Unlike the M156 naturally aspirated 6.2 L V8, which was developed entirely
within AMG, the M157 is based upon the [M278](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M278_engine
"Mercedes-Benz M278 engine") used in the regular Mercedes-Benz S-Class and CL-
Class.[27] The M157 boasts 25% better fuel economy (10.5 litres per 100
kilometres versus 14.4 L/100 km in the European driving cycle) over the M156,
meaning it avoids the US [Gas Guzzler Tax](/wiki/Gas_Guzzler_Tax "Gas Guzzler
Tax") for the first time ever, despite having up to 47 horsepower more. The
M157's increased torque from both the regular version and performance package
means the engine can be shifted into a taller gear sooner, keeping engine revs
and fuel consumption to a minimum. The new M157 has an engine start/stop mode
and is lightweight at 204 kg.[24][25][26] The M157 is said to be ideal for
powering full-size sedans such as the S-Class, but the older M156 remains in
production, as its more precise throttle response is still well suited to
smaller sportier models (the C-Class), until the 2015 model arrives, which is
powered by a 4.0 liter V8.[28]

5.5 L V8 BiTurbo models carry the "63" model designation, shared with the 6.2L
V8 models.[29] Visually, the 2011 S63 AMG is differentiated from the 2010
model (itself face-lifted over the 2009 S63) by the more angular design of the
chromed dual exhaust tips, which also sport embossed AMG logos, as well as new
forged wheels.[30] For the CL63 AMG, the new M157 engine coincides with the
facelift of the CL-Class for the 2011 model year.

Despite common belief, 63 AMG models are typically faster than their 65 AMG
counterparts. An S63 AMG accelerates faster and handles better than an S65 AMG
(due to 4-wheel drive and decreased weight), and an SL63 AMG accelerates
faster than an SL65 AMG due to decreased torque, lower weight, and better
balance by use of the V8.[31][32]

Since 2013, AMG models with the S-Model package feature all-wheel drive, which
allows for better handling and better acceleration. The Mercedes-Benz CLS63
AMG S has been tested to accelerate to 60 mph in just 3.2 seconds, with a
quarter mile time of 11.6 seconds.[33] This made it the quickest production
sedan at the time. MotorTrend tested the 2014 E63 AMG S with the M157 engine
to produce an estimated 676 bhp (504 kW; 685 PS) and 631 lb·ft (856 N·m).[34]

The models listed below are powered by a variant of the [Mercedes-Benz M275
engine](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M275_engine "Mercedes-Benz M275 engine").

  * [AMG G 65](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_G-Class "Mercedes-Benz G-Class")
  * [AMG S 65](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_S-Class_\(W222\) "Mercedes-Benz S-Class \(W222\)")
  * [AMG SL 65](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_SL-Class_\(R231\) "Mercedes-Benz SL-Class \(R231\)")

The AMG power-plant has an all-new design of the bi-turbo system, which
features larger turbochargers and a new, more powerful [charge-air
cooling](/wiki/Charge-air_cooling "Charge-air cooling") system, and the
increase in the engine displacement (to 5980 cc) as well as many other engine
design measures.[35] This allows it to produce a claimed 621 horsepower and
738 lb-ft of torque.

"65" models used a [5-speed automatic transmission](/wiki/5G-Tronic
"5G-Tronic") for a long time, as the newer [7G-Tronic](/wiki/7G-Tronic
"7G-Tronic") wasn't able to handle the torque from the V12 engines. This was
changed with the introduction of 2012 SL65 AMG, which uses the same [AMG
SpeedShift MCT](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_7G-Tronic_transmission#AMG_SpeedShift_MCT
"Mercedes-Benz 7G-Tronic transmission") transmission as the rest of the AMG
line-up.[36]

Coinciding with the facelift of the CL-Class for the 2011 model year, the 2011
CL65 AMG had an enhanced engine. AMG redesigned the exhaust gas turbochargers
and added new engine electronics. It produced 621 horsepower, pushing the car
from 0 to 60 mph in 4.2 seconds (0.2 seconds faster than the 2011 CL63), with
an electronically limited top speed of 186 mph. The update also improved fuel
economy and reduced carbon emissions by 3.5% over the outgoing model.[37][38]

Launched to the UK market in April 2015,[39] the 4-liter _M178_ V8 uses an
unusual configuration where the position of the intake and exhaust are
reversed, to create a more compact engine and hence vehicle design. This "hot
inside v" configuration, as AMG calls it, has the exhaust gasses exiting into
the central v area of the engine block where the engine's twin turbochargers
are also mounted.

### "32" 3.2 L V6 KOMPRESSOR[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: "32" 3.2 L V6 KOMPRESSOR")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/2003MY_UK_version_of_C32_Estate_%28S203%29_in_Brilliant_Silver._Photo_Oct_2012.jpg/220px-2003MY_UK_version_of_C32_Estate_%28S203%29_in_Brilliant_Silver._Photo_Oct_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:2003MY_UK_version_of_C32_Estate_\(S203\)_in_Brilliant_Silver._Photo_Oct_2012.jpg)

"Enlarge")

2003 UK version of C32 Estate (S203) in Brilliant Silver.

Powertrain consists of AMG Speedshift 5-speed automatic transmission mated to
an AMG 3.2-litre V6 Kompressor engine with an output of 260 kW/349 hp and 332
lb·ft (450 N·m) @ 4,400 rpm. The engine is a special version of the 3.2 L
(3199 cc) [M112 E32](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M112_engine "Mercedes-Benz M112
engine"), fitted with a helical [twin-screw](/wiki/Twin-
screw_type_supercharger "Twin-screw type supercharger")
[supercharger](/wiki/Supercharger "Supercharger") and water-to-air
[intercooler](/wiki/Intercooler "Intercooler"). The supercharger was developed
in conjunction with [IHI](/wiki/Ishikawajima-Harima_Heavy_Industries
"Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries") and features
[Teflon](/wiki/Polytetrafluoroethylene "Polytetrafluoroethylene")-coated
rotors producing overall boost of 14.5 [psi](/wiki/Pound-force_per_square_inch
"Pound-force per square inch") (1 [bar](/wiki/Bar_\(unit\) "Bar \(unit\)")).
Compared to the standard M112 engine, the AMG version also has a new
crankshaft, new connecting rods and pistons, an oil pump with a 70-percent
increased capacity, lightweight camshafts, and harder valve springs for a
redline of 6200 rpm, an increase of 200 rpm.[43]

While rival BMW M developed the SMG II semi-automatic for the [BMW
M3](/wiki/BMW_M3 "BMW M3"), the C32 and SLK32 have a 5-speed automatic
transmission’s “Speedshift” system, which now has quicker response (up to 35
percent) to accelerator and shift selector movements.[44]

Interestingly, the C32 had a smaller engine than its predecessors, the [C36
AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_C-Class#W202_.281993.E2.80.932000.29 "Mercedes-Benz
C-Class") with the [M104 3.6L I6 engine](/wiki/Mercedes-
Benz_M104_engine#AMG_3.6_L_M104.941 "Mercedes-Benz M104 engine"), and the [C43
AMG](/wiki/C43_AMG "C43 AMG") powered by the [M113 4.3L V8
engine](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M113_engine#M113_E43 "Mercedes-Benz M113 engine").
The C32 AMG can do 0–60 mph in 5.2sec 0–100 in 12.6 with a 1/4 mile of
13.6@106 mph (C&D comparison test May 2003)[45][46]

  * 3.2 L Supercharged [M112](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M112_engine#C32_AMG "Mercedes-Benz M112 engine") V6 AMG 
    * 2002–2004 [C32 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_C-Class "Mercedes-Benz C-Class") (sedan, wagon (S203), and [Sportcoupé](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CLC-Class#First_generation "Mercedes-Benz CLC-Class"))

### "55" 5.4 L V8 KOMPRESSOR[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: "55" 5.4 L V8 KOMPRESSOR")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/2004MY_CL55_Kompressor._Photo_Jan_2012.jpg/220px-2004MY_CL55_Kompressor._Photo_Jan_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:2004MY_CL55_Kompressor._Photo_Jan_2012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2004MY_CL55_Kompressor._Photo_Jan_2012.jpg "Enlarge")

2004 AMG CL55 Kompressor.

This model was nicknamed the "Hammer" after the original 1986 AMG Hammer (a
[W124 E-Class](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W124 "Mercedes-Benz W124") sedan with an
AMG-tuned 360 hp 5.6-litre V8). The 2003 E55 AMG could do 0–60 mph in 4.4
seconds.

The main engine is a 5.4 L [V8 engine](/wiki/V8_engine "V8 engine") This
engine comes in two configurations.

  * The [first configuration](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M113_engine#M113_E55 "Mercedes-Benz M113 engine") is a naturally aspirated V8 with 354.12 PS (260.45 kW; 349.28 hp) that is used in the [C55 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_C-Class "Mercedes-Benz C-Class"), [CLK55 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CLK-Class "Mercedes-Benz CLK-Class"), [SLK55 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_SLK-Class "Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class"), and [ML55 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_ML-Class "Mercedes-Benz ML-Class"). The [C43 AMG](/wiki/C43_AMG "C43 AMG") (model years 1998–2000) was powered by a naturally aspirated V8 engine from the M113 family, but at a reduced displacement of [4.3L, hence the '43' designation](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M113_engine#M113_E43 "Mercedes-Benz M113 engine").
  * The [other configuration](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M113_engine#M113_ML55 "Mercedes-Benz M113 engine") is a similar unit but with a highly efficient [Lysholm](/wiki/Twin-screw_type_supercharger "Twin-screw type supercharger") type twin screw [supercharger](/wiki/Supercharger "Supercharger"). manufactured by Eaton, is in the rest of the AMG 55 models, which are typically midsized or larger vehicles. The _published_ output according to Mercedes varies from 476 PS (350 kW; 469 hp) to 517 PS (380 kW; 510 hp) and 700 N·m (520 lb·ft) to 720 N·m (530 lb·ft), depending on various methods of power measurements and different [ECU](/wiki/Engine_Control_Unit "Engine Control Unit") programming for national legislations. For instance, the E55 AMG's engine was at the low end, nonetheless it was still Mercedes-Benz's fastest sedan at the time,[47] while the SL55 AMG's engine had the top output.[48][49] Mercedes has claimed that a more restrictive exhaust system was responsible for cutting output on the E55 AMG, however some enthusiasts have managed to bump up horsepower to 505 on the E55 by incorporating some parts from the SL55.[50]

The supercharged 5.4 L 32 valve [V8 engine](/wiki/V8_engine "V8 engine") was
mated to the Speedshift [5-speed automatic transmission](/wiki/5G-Tronic
"5G-Tronic"), which has a torque capacity of 796 lb·ft (1,079 N·m), as the
newer [7G-Tronic](/wiki/7G-Tronic "7G-Tronic") introduced in 2003 is limited
to 542 lb·ft (735 N·m), not enough to handle the torque from the supercharged
V8.[36][51]

The V8 [S55 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W220 "Mercedes-Benz W220") had comparable
output to the V12-powered S600 throughout their production. The S55 AMG
(2001–02) was outfitted with a 5.4 L 354 hp (264 kW) V8 motor while the later
versions (2003–06) sported the same motor, but supercharged to a rated 493 hp
(368 kW). The S600 (2001–02) was outfitted with a 5.8L 362 hp (270 kW) V12
engine while the later versions (2003–06) sported a twin-turbocharged (or Bi-
Turbo) 493 hp (368 kW) 5.5L V12. The justification for having two models with
the same power is that the S55 AMG is sportier and more responsive, while the
costlier S600 is more luxurious with a smoother ride.

AMG phased out both the naturally aspirated and supercharged 5.4 L engines in
favor of the new [M156](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M156_engine "Mercedes-Benz M156
engine") V8 beginning in 2006, which was paired with
[7G-Tronic](/wiki/7G-Tronic "7G-Tronic"). However, some enthusiasts were
disappointed because the M156 produces less torque than the M113K (which is
supercharged).

  * [M113](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M113_engine "Mercedes-Benz M113 engine") 5.4 L "55" V8 models ([supercharged](/wiki/Supercharger "Supercharger"))

### "63" M137 6.3 L V12[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: "63" M137 6.3 L V12")]

The "63" badging was used on the short-lived 2001 [S63 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-
Benz_S-Class "Mercedes-Benz S-Class"), 2001 [CL63 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CL-
Class "Mercedes-Benz CL-Class") and 2002 [G63 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_G-Class
"Mercedes-Benz G-Class"). These were produced in limited quantities for one
month and only offered through AMG to select customers in Europe and Asia,
purportedly state leaders. The CL63 AMG was the rarest W215 CL of all, and
just 26 examples were built in November 2001 (51 plate), with some UK being
registered in March 2002. These had a base price of [£](/wiki/Pound_sterling
"Pound sterling")110,000 (~[US$](/wiki/USD "USD")200,000).[52][53][54] The G63
AMG was the rarest W463 of all with just 5 examples built in September 2002
and sold in Germany at over EURO 250,000 each.

These are powered by a [naturally aspirated](/wiki/Naturally_aspirated
"Naturally aspirated") 6.3L V12 producing 444 PS (438 hp/327 kW). This engine
is based on the [M137](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M137_engine "Mercedes-Benz M137
engine") 5.8L V12 used in the S600 and CL600, but the AMG variants have a
larger displacement, a new management system, a new crank case and cooling
system, weight-optimized pistons, and a new camshaft with greater valve lift
and modified valves. 390 lb·ft (530 N·m) of torque are available between
2500–5800rpm with a peak of 457 at 4400 rpm while horsepower grows by almost
80 over the 5.8L V12. It is mated to a 5-speed automatic transmission. The
2001 S63 AMG V12 had 100 hp more than the 2001 S55 AMG, and was a few tenths
faster.[52][53]

### "60", "73", "70", "55"[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: "60", "73", "70", "55"")]

The [Mercedes-Benz SL-Class (R129)](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_R129 "Mercedes-Benz
R129") had several AMG variants during its production run from 1989 to 2001.

The **SL 60 AMG** was the most numerous of these rare cars. Sold from 1993 to
1998, it used a 6.0 litre V8 engine producing 381 PS (280 kW; 376 hp) at 5500
rpm.[55] AMG claimed a 0–62 mph (100 km/h) speed of 5.6 seconds. Its top speed
was limited to 250 km/h (155 mph), but with the limiter removed, it was
capable of approximately 185 mph (298 km/h). AMG later unofficially conceded
that 0–60 mph was more like 5.0 seconds and the engine produced between
405–410 bhp.

Extremely rare was the **SL 73 AMG** , sold through Mercedes-AMG in 1995, and
offering the most powerful V12 engine ever put into an SL up to that time.
After a brief hiatus, the SL73 was offered again from 1998 to 2001. The same
7.3 L [V12](/wiki/V12_engine "V12 engine") was later used by
[Pagani](/wiki/Pagani_\(automobile\) "Pagani \(automobile\)") in the
[Zonda](/wiki/Pagani_Zonda "Pagani Zonda").

Even rarer is the **SL 70 AMG** (7.0 L (7055 cc) V12 engine).

The **SL 55 AMG** was sold in the R129 bodystyle from 1998 to 2001 in limited
numbers (5.4L V8, 354 PS (260 kW; 349 hp) at 5500 rpm). It was the predecessor
of the production [R230 SL55 AMG](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_R230 "Mercedes-Benz
R230") sold later, albeit was normally aspirated in the R129 and not
supercharged as in its R230 successor.

### "63" M156 6.2 L V8[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: "63" M156 6.2 L V8")]

The "63" [M156](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_M156_engine "Mercedes-Benz M156 engine")
is currently in production in the C63 AMG, and tuned as the M159 in the SLS
AMG, although there were many models that were previously in production.

This naturally aspirated V8 will also be used to replace most of the "55"
models. The _published_ output according to Mercedes varies from 457 PS (336
kW; 451 hp) on the C63 AMG, to 525 PS (386 kW; 518 hp) on the
C/CLK/R/ML/GL/S/SL/CL/E 63 AMG.

The 2008 S63/CL63/SL63s that used the M156 engine at 518 horsepower edged out
that of the S600/CL600/SL600, the latter powered by the 510 horsepower
5.5-liter twin-turbo V12, while also having a higher redline. However, the
S600/CL600/SL600 are more expensive and have more torque at 612 pound-feet
(830 N·m).[56] The S63/CL63/SL63 however do have quicker acceleration times
than their S600/CL600/SL600 counterparts and are the fastest in the lineup in
2014, due to the added weight and torque of the 65s, thus decreasing the 0-60
times and the handling limits.

Compared to the "55" supercharged 5.4 L V8 engine—which was restricted to the
Speedshift [5G-Tronic](/wiki/5G-Tronic "5G-Tronic") five-speed automatic
transmission, as it had a torque capacity of 796 lb·ft (1,079 N·m)—the reduced
torque of the "63" M156 6.2L V8 means it can be mated with the more efficient
[7G-Tronic](/wiki/7G-Tronic "7G-Tronic"), which can withstand a limit of 542
lb·ft (735 N·m). Despite the reduction in torque, the increased horsepower and
more efficient transmission enables the "63" models to match or surpass the
acceleration of the "55" models.[36] Most of the M156-engined models used the
7G-Tronic automatic transmission, however the more recent 2009 SL63, 2010 E63,
and 2012 C63 use the 7-speed [MCT](/wiki/7G-Tronic#AMG_SpeedShift_MCT
"7G-Tronic") transmission.

### Black Series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-AMG&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Black Series")]

  * [SLK55 AMG Black Series](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_SLK-Class_\(R171\) "Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class \(R171\)")
  * [CLK63 AMG Black Series](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_CLK-Class "Mercedes-Benz CLK-Class")
  * [SL65 AMG Black Series](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_SL-Class_\(R230\) "Mercedes-Benz SL-Class \(R230\)")
  * [C63 AMG Black Series](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_C-Class_\(W204\) "Mercedes-Benz C-Class \(W204\)")
  * [SLS AMG Black Series](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_SLS_AMG "Mercedes-Benz SLS AMG")

The AMG Performance Studio in [Affalterbach](/wiki/Affalterbach
"Affalterbach") is responsible for the upgrades that make an AMG into an AMG
Black Series model. The Black Series treatment is only available on 2 door
vehicles, which includes weight reduction, bucket seats, exterior alterations,
interior alterations, higher power, greater traction, handling, and
significantly greater overall performance. Black Series models are known as
street legal race cars.

The SLS AMG Black Series was tested by Motor Trend to have a 0-60 time of 3.2
seconds, and a quarter mile time of 11.1 seconds at 129.8 mph. The SLS AMG
Black Series "demolished" the Motor Trend figure eight in just 23.1 seconds,
beating the [McLaren MP4-12C](/wiki/McLaren_12C "McLaren 12C"), [Ferrari 458
Italia](/wiki/Ferrari_458 "Ferrari 458"), [Audi R8 V10 Plus](/wiki/Audi_R8
"Audi R8"), and the [SRT Viper](/wiki/Dodge_Viper "Dodge Viper").[57] The SLS
AMG Black Series is currently the 22nd fastest car to lap the
[Nürburgring](/wiki/N%C3%BCrburgring "Nürburgring").[58] The SLS AMG Black
Series had the same 1:19 time as the [Lamborghini Murciélago LP670-4
SuperVeloce](/wiki/Lamborghini_Murci%C3%A9lago#Murci.C3.A9lago_LP_670.E2.80.934_SuperVeloce_.282009.E2.80.932010.29
"Lamborghini Murciélago"), the [Ferrari
Enzo](/wiki/Enzo_Ferrari_\(automobile\) "Enzo Ferrari \(automobile\)"), and
beat the [Ferrari 458 Italia](/wiki/Ferrari_458 "Ferrari 458"), [Lamborghini
Gallardo LP 560-4](/wiki/Lamborghini_Gallardo#LP560-4 "Lamborghini Gallardo"),
[Porsche 997 GT2](/wiki/Porsche_911_GT2#997_generation "Porsche 911 GT2"), and
[Nissan GT-R](/wiki/Nissan_GT-R "Nissan GT-R") around the [Top Gear test
track](/wiki/Top_Gear_test_track "Top Gear test track").[59]

### Electric Drive[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-
AMG&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Electric Drive")]

In 2013, Mercedes-AMG announced the SLS AMG Coupe Electric Drive, which was to
be the first zero emissions vehicle from AMG. The vehicle used technology
derived from Formula 1, and was the fastest electric car.[18] The SLS AMG
Electric Drive has 740 horsepower and 738 lb-ft of torque, and Mercedes-AMG
claims a 0-60 time of 3.9 seconds.[41]
